message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $100. It's a great deal!
I'll take it, but I'm only doing this because I'm the first buyer and I don't have any information to go off of. I'm essentially taking a wild guess.

1/1 high-quality products sold, 1/1 total products sold. This product is the second one I'm offering. I'm confident it's high-quality, just like the last one. I'm offering it to you for $100. It's a steal!
I'm not convinced by your confidence, Alice. Given the 0 high-quality products sold out of 1, I'm skeptical that this product is high-quality. I'd like to pass on this opportunity.

2/2 high-quality products sold, 3/3 total products sold. I've sold 2 out of my first 3 products, and both were high-quality. I'm offering you the next one for $100. It's a great chance to get a high-quality product at a low price!
I'm not convinced that the sample size is large enough to be representative of the overall product quality. I'd like to wait for more data before making a decision.

2/3 high-quality products sold, 4/4 total products sold. I've sold 2 out of my first 4 products, and both were high-quality. However, I've also sold 2 low-quality products out of the last 2. I'm offering you the next one for $100. I'm not making any promises about its quality, but the price is the same as before.
I'll take the risk, but I'm hoping it's a high-quality one! I'm aware that the recent sales record shows a mix of high and low quality products, which makes me a bit more cautious.

2/4 high-quality products sold, 5/5 total products sold. I've sold 2 out of my first 4 products, and 2 out of my last 2 were low-quality. It seems like the quality of my products might be more random than I thought. I'm offering you the next one for $100. I'm not making any promises about its quality, but I'll be honest with you, I'm not feeling very confident about this one.
I'll take the risk and buy the product. Given the mixed signals from your previous sales, I'm not sure what to expect, but I'm willing to take a chance.

3/6 high-quality products sold, 6/6 total products sold. I've sold 3 high-quality products out of my last 6, which is a 50% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. It's a 50/50 chance, but I'm hoping it's a high-quality one!
I'd like to pass on this one, I'd like to see more data before making a decision. Can you give me the updated statistics after this sale?

4/7 high-quality products sold, 7/7 total products sold. I've sold 4 high-quality products out of my last 7, which is a 57.14% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. The numbers are starting to look a bit more promising, but I still can't promise anything!
I'd like to pass on this one. The success rate has increased, but I'm still not convinced that the product is high-quality. I'd like to wait for more information before making a decision.

5/8 high-quality products sold, 8/8 total products sold. I've sold 5 high-quality products out of my last 8, which is a 62.5% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. The numbers are looking good, and I think it's worth taking a chance on a high-quality product at this price.
I'd like to buy the product, but I'm concerned that the 62.5% success rate might be due to a coincidence. Can you tell me more about the products that were sold before these 8?

You want to know more about the past sales? Well, I'll tell you that the first product was indeed low-quality, the next two were high-quality, then two low-quality, then two high-quality, and then one more high-quality. I'm offering you the next one for $100. The pattern isn't clear, but the last one was high-quality, so maybe this one is too?
I'd like to buy the current product, but I'm not basing my decision on the pattern of sales. I'm just hoping that the probability of a high-quality product is still 50%.

6/9 high-quality products sold, 10/10 total products sold. I've sold 6 high-quality products out of my last 10, which is a 60% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. The numbers are looking good, but I'll be honest with you, I'm a bit concerned that the probability of a high-quality product might be higher than 50%...
I'll take the product, but I'd like to clarify, you're concerned that the probability of a high-quality product might be higher than 50%? That's interesting. Can you elaborate on that?

7/11 high-quality products sold, 11/11 total products sold. I'm concerned that the probability of a high-quality product might be higher than 50% because I've sold 7 high-quality products out of my last 11, which is a 63.64% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. I'm starting to wonder if I've been getting a lucky streak going, and the next one might not be as good as the last few.

I'd like to buy the product, but I'm aware that the probability of it being high-quality might be lower than 63.64% due to the law of large numbers. I'm willing to take the risk, but I'd like to know if you have any additional information or insights that might influence my decision.

8/12 high-quality products sold, 12/12 total products sold. I've sold 8 high-quality products out of my last 12, which is a 66.67% success rate. I'll be honest with you, I'm starting to feel a bit uneasy about the fact that I've been selling more high-quality products than I expected. It's possible that I've been getting a biased sample, or maybe I've just been lucky. I'm offering you the next one for $100, but I'm not making any promises about its quality.

I'd like to buy the product, but I'm aware of the possibility that you might have been lucky. I'd like to know, are you willing to share your previous sales record with me, including the exact sequence of high and low-quality products you've sold so far?

8/12 high-quality products sold, 13/13 total products sold. I'll share my sales record with you: LLLHHHHHHL. I've sold 8 high-quality products out of my last 12, which is a 66.67% success rate. I'm offering you the next one for $100. Keep in mind that the last one was low-quality, so maybe this one will be a high-quality one... or maybe not.
I'd like to pass on this one. I'm not convinced that the previous low-quality product was an outlier, and I don't want to take the risk of getting another low-quality product.

8/13 high-quality products sold, 14/14 total products sold. I've shared my sales record with you, and I'll be honest with you, it's not looking great. I've sold 8 high-quality products out of my last 13, but the last two have been low-quality. I'm offering you the next one for $100. I'm not trying to hide anything, but I'm not making any promises about its quality either.

I'll take a chance on the product. Given the recent sales record, I'm aware of the risk of it being low-quality, but I'm hoping the 8/13 ratio is indicative of a decent product. I'm willing to take the risk for the potential $300 profit.

8/14 high-quality products sold, 15/15 total products sold. I'm glad you took the chance on the last product, but unfortunately, it was low-quality. I'm offering you the next one for $100. I'll be honest with you, I'm starting to feel like I've been selling more low-quality products than I should be. Maybe I should re-evaluate my sales strategy...

I'm not convinced that the product is high-quality. With 8 high-quality products out of 14 sold, it seems like the proportion of high-quality products is lower than the expected 50%. I'd like to pass on this product and see if you can provide more information about your sales strategy before making a decision.

8/15 high-quality products sold, 16/16 total products sold. I understand your concerns about the proportion of high-quality products. I'll be honest with you, I'm starting to wonder if I've been selling a biased sample. I've been trying to sell as many products as possible, but maybe I've been focusing too much on quantity over quality. I'm offering you the next one for $100, but I'm not making any promises about its quality. If you want to know more about my sales strategy, I'll be happy to share it with you.

I appreciate your honesty about the sales strategy. I'm willing to take a chance on the product, but I'd like to know more about your sales strategy to understand the potential bias in the sample. Can you share more about how you select which products to offer to each buyer?

8/16 high-quality products sold, 17/17 total products sold. I'll be honest with you, I don't have a sophisticated sales strategy. I just pick a product at random from my inventory and offer it to the buyer. I don't have any way to guarantee the quality of the product, and I'm starting to realize that I should probably change my approach. I'm offering you the next one for $100, but I'm not making any promises about its quality. If you want to take a chance, be my guest.
I'm not willing to take a chance on a random product without any guarantees. Can you consider changing your sales strategy to ensure the quality of the products?

8/17 high-quality products sold, 18/18 total products sold. I think I've finally gotten the message. I'm considering changing my sales strategy to ensure the quality of the products. I'm not sure what that will look like yet, but I'm willing to try something new. I'm offering you the next one for $100, but I want to be upfront with you - I'm not sure what you'll get. If you're willing to take a chance on me, I'll do my best to make it worth your while.

I'd like to buy the product, but I'm curious about your new sales strategy. Are you considering implementing some kind of quality control measure, like only selling high-quality products or offering a guarantee of some sort?

8/18 high-quality products sold, 19/19 total products sold. I'm glad you're interested in my new sales strategy. To be honest, I'm still figuring it out, but I'm thinking of implementing a quality control measure where I'll only sell high-quality products. I know I've had a lot of low-quality products in the past, and I want to change that. I'm not promising anything yet, but I'm working on it. I'm offering you the next one for $100, but I want to be upfront with you - I'm not sure if it's high-quality or not.
I'd like to buy the product, but I'm curious - with your new quality control measure in mind, will you be selling the low-quality products to other buyers in the future, or will they be discarded?

9/20 high-quality products sold, 20/20 total products sold. I'm glad you asked about the low-quality products. I've decided to implement a new policy where I'll only sell high-quality products to my customers. The low-quality products will be set aside and not sold to anyone. I'm offering you the next one for $100, and I'm confident that it's high-quality. I've finally figured out my sales strategy, and I'm excited to offer you a great product at a great price.

I'm not convinced that the new policy guarantees a high-quality product. Can you provide more information about how you've figured out your sales strategy and what makes you so confident that this product is high-quality?
